question: Question_B_05_(a)
statement:
Consider the differential equation system

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y}' = A\mathbf{y} ~\end{align*} where \emph{A} has an eigenvalue
$\lambda_1 = 1 + 2i$ with corresponding eigenvector

\begin{align*}\mathbf{k}_{1}=\left[ \begin{array}{c}
2+3i\\
1
\end{array} \right]\end{align*}

Recall that for real matrices, eigenvalues and eigenvectors come in
complex conjugate pairs.

Write the general solution of the system of differential equations. This
can be written in real or complex form.
sols:
There are 3 sections in this page but only the first section is ``what
is supposed to be written'' in the exam.

\subsection{Solution}\label{solution}

Since eigenvalues and eigenvectors occur in conjugate pairs for the real
matrix \emph{A}, the other pair is:

\begin{align*} 
\lambda_2 &= 1-2i \\
\mathbf{k}_2 &= \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2-3i \\ 1 \end{array}\right]\end{align*}

The general solution is then:

\begin{align*}
y &= C_1 \mathbf{k}_1 \exp{\lambda_1 t} + C_2 \mathbf{k}_2 \exp{\lambda_2 t} \\
&= C_1 \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2+3i \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \exp((1+2i) t) + C_2 \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2-3i \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \exp((1-2i)t)\end{align*}

We delay showing how to write it into real form to
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH152/April 2010/Question B5 (b)/Solution 1}{part
(b)}.

\subsection{Motivation}\label{motivation}

To see a reason why this is so. Let us recall that $e^{at}$ solves
$x' = ax$ which is the single equation analogue of the given system.
From this, we can make a guess that a constant vector times an
exponential function might solve our system. More precisely, we
substitute the guess $\mathbf{v} e^{ct}$ into the system to get (both
$\mathbf{v}, c$ are to be determined):

\begin{align*}
(\mathbf{v} e^{ct})' &= A \mathbf{v} e^{ct} \\
c \mathbf{v} e^{ct} &= A \mathbf{v} e^{ct} \\
c \mathbf{v} &= A \mathbf{v} \end{align*}

(The cancellation in the last step is because the exponential function
is always positive). So it turns out for our guess to work, \emph{c} and
\textbf{v} as a pair must solve the eigenvalue problem
$A \mathbf{v} = c \mathbf{v}$, i.e. they must be a pair of eigenvalue
and eigenvector of \emph{A}!

Now, from the two pairs of eigenvalues and eigenvectors we know, we have
the following solutions:

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y}_1 = \mathbf{k}_1 e^{\lambda_1 t}\end{align*}

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y}_2 = \mathbf{k}_2 e^{\lambda_2 t}\end{align*}

To be precise, we should say they are just \emph{particular} solutions
of the problem. To obtain the formula of the general solution, we
observe that the differential equation system is linear and so a linear
combination of $\mathbf{y}_1$ and $\mathbf{y}_2$, i.e.

\begin{align*}\mathbf{y} = C_1 \mathbf{y}_1 + C_2 \mathbf{y}_2\end{align*}

solves the system too:

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{y} &= \left( C_1 \mathbf{y}_1 + C_2 \mathbf{y}_2 \right)' \\
&= C_1 \mathbf{y}_1' + C_2 \mathbf{y}_2' \\
&= C_1 A \mathbf{y}_1 + C_2 A \mathbf{y}_2 \\
&= A \left( C_1 \mathbf{y}_1 + C_2 \mathbf{y}_2 \right) \\
&= A \mathbf{y}\end{align*}

It turns out this represents all possible solutions.

\subsection{Extended Reading}\label{extended-reading}

The following outlines the general method to deduce the general solution
systematically (in the syllabus of Math 215/255). The key is to see that
the existence of the two pairs of eigenvalues and eigenvectors of
\emph{A} allows us to ``diagonalize'' the matrix \emph{A}.

In fact, once we have found all the eigenvalues and corresponding
eigenvectors, if the number of eigenvectors equals the rank of the
matrix \emph{A} (in this case, it is \emph{2}), then we can rewrite
\emph{A} into the following form (known as the diagonalization of
\emph{A}):

\begin{align*}A = VDV^{-1} ~\end{align*} where

\begin{align*}V = 
\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
\mathbf{k}_1 & \mathbf{k}_2
\end{array}\right] = 
\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
2+3i & 2-3i\\
1 & 1
\end{array}\right]\end{align*}

\begin{align*}D = 
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\lambda_1 & 0\\
0 & \lambda_2
\end{array}\right] = 
\left[\begin{array}{cc}
1+2i & 0\\
0 & 1-2i
\end{array}\right].\end{align*}

To solve the given linear system of differential equations, we proceed
as follows exploiting the diagonalizability of \emph{A}.

Left multiplying $V^{-1}$ on both sides of the linear system gives:

\begin{align*}V^{-1}\mathbf{y}' = DV^{-1} \mathbf{y}\end{align*}

So if we let

\begin{align*}\mathbf{x} = V^{-1} \mathbf{y}\end{align*}

Then, we get a simple decoupled system for
$\mathbf{x} = \left[ \begin{array}{c} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{array} \right]$
(see note):

\begin{align*}\left\{ \begin{array}{ccc}
x_{1}' &&= \lambda_{1}x_{1}\\
x_{2}' &&= \lambda_{2}x_{2}
\end{array}\right.\end{align*}

The general solution must then be:

\begin{align*}\mathbf{x} 
= \left[ \begin{array}{c} C_1 \exp{\lambda_1 t} \\ C_2 \exp{\lambda_2 t} \end{array} \right] 
= \left[ \begin{array}{c} C_1 \exp{(1+2i)t} \\ C_2 \exp{(1-2i) t)} \end{array} \right]\end{align*}:

Therefore,

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{y} &=  V \mathbf{x} \\
~ &= \left[ \begin{array}{cc} \mathbf{k}_1 & \mathbf{k}_2 \end{array}\right] 
\left[ \begin{array}{c} C_1 \exp{\lambda_1 t} \\ C_2 \exp{\lambda_2 t} \end{array} \right] \\
~ &= C_1 \mathbf{k}_1 \exp{\lambda_1 t} + C_2 \mathbf{k}_2 \exp{\lambda_2 t} \\
~ &= C_1 \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2+3i \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \exp{(1+2i) t} + 
C_2 \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2-3i \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \exp{(1-2i) t}\end{align*}

where $C_1, C_2 ~$ are complex constants.

\textbf{Note}: The word \emph{decoupled} means the equations can be
regarded separately as single equations themselves, i.e. this
\emph{system} is just a collection of single equations whose solutions
do not affect each other.
hints:
What happens if you substitute

\begin{align*}\mathbf{v} e^{\lambda_1 t}\end{align*}

into the equation?

What must $\mathbf{v}$ be?

One particular solution to the equation can be found using the given
pair of eigenvalue and eigenvector. What is the other pair of eigenvalue
and eigenvector? How can you combine these two solutions to form the
general solution?
